results.title: The XPT East Coast journey
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
On the Express Passenger Train- Australia’s fastest train, travel from Brisbane in subtropical Queensland to cosmopolitan Sydney in the heart of New South Wales. Cross the rugged Macpherson ranges, tour Australia’s economic heartland and visit the country’s pristine beaches. The XPT even cruises through some alternative villages and through Australia’s spectacular rainforests. As the train pulls into one of its 21 stops, Coff’s Harbour, view the vast plantations of bananas as well as the gaudy “Big Banana” tourist park, which symbolizes the recent tourism boom. Finally, the XPT reaches Sydney. Hugging the shores of a magnificent harbor and accented by its elegant bridge, Sydney is the quintessential icon of the Australian experience.

results.title: Groupthink
results.creator_credit: Steven Katten, Communication Research Materials Production and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Group Dynamics”.
Analyses the dynamics of group decision-making and explores the processes which inhibit creativity and foster “groupthink”.

results.title: Who's responsible?
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande and JW Newman Corp
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
I am the cause of my own effects. This is a difficult concept for many to accept; most people prefer to “blame” others or environment for what happens to them. Teenagers attending a PACE conference deal with the concept of responsibility. Their discussions highlight how ‘what happens to you is under your own control to a very great extent’ and that, by exercising your choice, you can ‘create the effect your want to have in your life’.

results.title: The Queenslander: tales of the tropical north
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
When you leave Brisbane on the Queenslander, you find yourself on an adventure that seems larger than life. It’s a glorious luxury holiday train, reminiscent of the exotic rail journeys of last century. And there’s plenty of time to be drawn into it. The journey takes the better part of two days, travelling over 1,000 miles up the tropical coast to Cairns in the far north of Queensland. Pass through lush forests, unusual peaks and tiny towns, pineapple and banana plantations, grazing cattle and miles of sugarcane. Meet travellers from all over the world, including young backpackers, families on holiday and wealthy tourists, each with their own perspective on the Australian experience.

results.title: Kids, parents and pressures
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande, Robert Sande Productions and Bailey Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
Teenagers attending a PACE Seminar identify some of the everyday pressures and tensions that confront them. With the help of highly qualified instructors, they learn they are in control of their own attitudes and work out positive and effective ways of improving their attitudes and relieving pressures.

results.title: Growth and propagation
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
The concept of vegetative propagation is explained and how new plant cells are created in the growing points or meristems of plants. Discusses the importing of flower cuttings into Australia and the growing of potatoes. Using two case studies, the viewer is shown tissue culture techniques used to combat the plant disease Phytophthora, or “Jarrah dieback” and how genetic engineering is used to create a Blue Rose.

results.title: After the harvest
results.creator_credit: Robin Wischusen, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Overviews the marketing of horticultural products in both domestic and international markets with basic marketing principles being applied to specialised products from the commercial garden. Topics discussed: understanding the market, buyer behaviour, packaging, storage, the impact of chemical use, pricing, competition, market research and an analysis of the technological developments which ensure a product is delivered in a marketable condition.
